content.raw: Why are we setting `CMAKE_*_FLAGS` manually like this?  Those variables should be set by CMake as a result of setting the `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`.  From the docs on `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`: "For example, if CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE is Debug, then CMAKE_C_FLAGS_DEBUG will be added to the CMAKE_C_FLAGS".

content.raw:
Umm interesting. I have found that sentence in 2.6 documentation but no in 2.8 and if I remove them from our code, the final ```CMAKE_C_FLAGS``` are empty.

I also made a stupid test case and I can not reproduce the effect of automatically get Debug values added to CMAKE_C_FLAGS:

```
#!cmake

PROJECT(lala)

set (CMAKE_C_FLAGS_DEBUG " -ggdb3")
message(STATUS "C_FLAGS_DEBUG: ${CMAKE_C_FLAGS_DEBUG}")
message(STATUS "C_FLAGS: ${CMAKE_C_FLAGS}")
```

pullrequest.title: Support only standard CMAKE format for BUILD_TYPES

content.raw:
Note that we are currently supporting several formats for build types, ie: Debug and DEBUG. I'm planning on another pull request which use this variable to pull googe-perf dependency check when Profile mode is enabled. I need to change the order of calling SearchForStuff.cmake and change the STREQUAL check there by BUILD_TYPE_PROFILE variable, which saves duplicate code.

Once we change to only support the standard build types, then I see no reason to keep this variables defined, a single STREQUAL should be enough.
